name: bandoneon
definition: A musical instrument similar to a large concertina, especially popular in Latin America.
description:
The bandoneon is a type of concertina particularly popular in Argentina, Uruguay, and Lithuania.

Bandoneon is a bisonoric instrument. A given button produces different notes on the push and the pull.

It is an essential instrument in most tango ensembles from the traditional orquesta tipica of the 1910s onwards.

The bandoneon was originally intended as an instrument for religious and popular music of the day, in contrast to its predecessor, concertina, which had predominantly been used in folk music.

The bandoneon is held between both hands, with pushing and pulling motions forcing air through its bellows, which is routed through reeds by pressing its buttons.

As with other concertinas, the button action is in parallel to the motion of the bellows, and not perpendicular to it as with an accordion.

featured.caption: Bandoneon is extremely conducive to the sounds of tango.

facts.name: Introduced to Argentina by emigrants
facts.value: Around 1870, German and Italian emigrants and sailors brought the instrument to Argentina, where it was adopted into the nascent genre of tango music, a descendant of the earlier milonga.

facts.name: Difficult to play it
facts.value: The bandoneon is a complex instrument because most of the buttons produce a different note when played pushing in than when played pulling out.

facts.name: Left and right buttons layout are different.
facts.value: Beside being bisonoric, the right and left hand layouts are also different. A musician must learn four different keyboard layouts to play the instrument.

facts.name: Looks like a miniaturized accordion
facts.value: The bandoneon is a type of concertina, a free-reed musical instruments that looks like a miniaturized accordion, with a user accessible keys and switches on both sides of the device.

facts.name: Ástor Piazzolla
facts.value: Ástor Piazzolla, the late Argentinean tango composer and performer, was the leading exponent of the bandoneon in the 20th century.

facts.name: Popular for tango dance
facts.value: Bandoneon became very popular in Argentina at about 1890 when it was found to be extremely conducive to the sounds of tango.

related.definition: A portable wind instrument with a small keyboard and free metal reeds that sound when air is forced past them by pleated bellows operated by the player.
